sections.title: Why Every Adult Needs a Plan
sections.content: Without documented wishes, state intestacy laws decide who receives your assets and who manages the process. A will and, when appropriate, a trust provide clarity, speed, and privacy for loved ones.

points.title: Testator & Executor
points.description: You (the testator) state your wishes; the executor carries them out. Choose someone organized, trustworthy, and available.

points.title: Guardianship
points.description: Name guardians for minor children; have a conversation before listing them to confirm willingness.

points.title: Asset Instructions
points.description: Detail how property, accounts, and personal items are distributed. Use percentages or tiers to stay flexible.

sections.title: Trusts Add Control
sections.content: Trusts allow you to manage how and when beneficiaries receive assetsâ€”ideal for minor children, blended families, or special-needs planning.

sections.title: Estate Basics Checklist
steps: List guardians, executors, and backup choices.
Draft instructions for personal property and digital accounts.
Consult an estate attorney to tailor documents to your state.
Store documents securely and share locations with trusted contacts.

sections.title: Update After Milestones
sections.content: Revisit documents after marriage, divorce, births, major purchases, or moving across state lines.
